metadata.case_name: Life Insurance Corporation of India v. Sunil Kumar Mukherjee & Ors.

facts.text: Sunil Kumar Mukherjee employed in insurance line since June 1941, confirmed by Metropolitan Insurance Co. Ltd. in March 1950, working as Inspector since about 1953, holding appointment as Inspector at Barrackpore since March 18, 1955.

Appointment letter dated 18th or 19th March 1955 by Metropolitan Insurance Co. Ltd. as whole-time Inspector, containing 14 clauses; Clause 13 provided termination without notice for fraud, misappropriation, breach of discipline etc., or 30 days notice for other reasons.

Life Insurance Corporation took over controlled business of Metropolitan Insurance Co. Ltd.; order dated 14th February 1958 required Mukherjee to work as Field Officer attached to Barrackpore Branch Office until further orders.

Termination order dated 16th October 1958: services terminated with immediate effect in terms of section 5 of Categorisation circular of 2nd December 1957, based on Special Committee review of Ex-Branch Secretaries etc., accepted by Corporation; paid emoluments up to current month and one month's salary in lieu of notice.

Mukherjee filed writ petition under Art. 226 in Calcutta High Court praying for certiorari quashing termination order; Sinha J. allowed petition, issued certiorari and mandamus directing implementation.
Appellants preferred Letters Patent appeal; Bose C.J. and Debabrata Mookerji J. confirmed Sinha J.'s order; certificate of fitness granted for appeal to Supreme Court.

Similar facts in other 14 appeals from Calcutta High Court judgments/orders dated July 26 and August 1, 1962 in Appeals from Original Orders Nos. 288, 274-276, 278, 280, 279, 281, 273, 272, 271, 270, 269, 282 and 292 of 1961.

Nationalisation history: Life Insurance (Emergency Provisions) Ordinance No. 1 of 1956 promulgated 19th January 1956; replaced by Act No. 9 of 1956 effective 21st March 1956; followed by Act 31 of 1956 published 1st July 1956, appointed day 1st September 1956.
Section 7 of Act 31/1956: on appointed day, all assets and liabilities of controlled business of insurers vested in Corporation.

Section 11(1): whole-time employees of insurers in controlled business became employees of Corporation on appointed day, holding office by same tenure, remuneration, terms, conditions, rights as before, until terminated or altered.

Central Government order dated 30th December 1957 (blue order) under s.11(2): altered remuneration and terms for Field Officers (later Development Officers) to secure uniformity and interests of Corporation/policy-holders.

Blue order Clause 10: (a) termination for unsatisfactory performance, negligence, misconduct etc. after opportunity to show cause and enquiry; (b) termination without reason with prior approval of Chairman after 3 months notice.
Circulars by Managing Director: 30th September 1957 and 2nd December 1957; latter incorporated via Regulations.

Regulations 1958 under s.49 read with Clause 11 of Order: Regulation 4(3) refers to 2nd December 1957 circular principles for judging work; para 4(h): if performance <50% revised quota, refer to Zonal Committee for review, possible termination if poor performance not due to circumstances beyond control etc.
No enquiry held or opportunity given under Clause 10(a); no termination under Clause 10(b) with Chairman's approval.
Haridas Roy (Appeal No. 917/1963): appointed Field Officer 15th Feb 1958; 9th Aug 1958 offered absorption as Assistant, declined; terminated 18th Sep 1958 for refusing, poor quality work.

legal_issues.text: Whether the orders terminating services of respondents (Field/Development Officers) were valid, particularly whether termination under para 4(h) of 2nd Dec 1957 circular (incorporated in Regulations) required compliance with Clause 10 of 30th Dec 1957 Order.
Effect of 14th Feb 1958 appointment order as Field Officer post-takeover.

petitioner_arguments.text: High Court erred in holding termination orders invalid; power to terminate under para 4(h) and para 5 of circular independent of Clause 10 of Order; applied to incompetent/unwilling officers in interests of Corporation/policy-holders.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Categorisation circular 2 Dec 1957 para 4(h), Regulations 1958 incorporating circular

petitioner_arguments.text: For Haridas Roy, termination valid under para 4(h) or s.11(2).

respondent_arguments.text: Termination can only be under Clause 10(a) or 10(b) of Order; neither complied with (no enquiry/opportunity under 10(a), no Chairman approval/3 months notice under 10(b)); impugned orders invalid.

court_reasoning.text: s.11(1) transferred employees with same terms until altered; s.11(2) empowers Central Govt to alter terms notwithstanding s.11(1) etc.; Order under s.11(2) prevails over Regulations which cannot be inconsistent.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Hierarchy: s.11(2) paramount, then Order, then Regulations.

court_reasoning.text: Order provides self-contained terms including Clause 10 for termination; para 4(h) of circular (via Regulations) for fixing remuneration within Development Officer category; cannot independently terminate without Clause 10 compliance.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Para 4(h) makes officers liable to termination under Clause 10, not independent power.

court_reasoning.text: 14 Feb 1958 order appointed as Field Officer under Govt Order, subjecting to blue Order terms.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Employees carried original terms until Order altered them.

court_reasoning.text: Haridas Roy case not distinguishable: absorption as Assistant beyond Regulations scope; termination must follow Clause 10.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Could fix minimum pay under Clause 5, invoke s.11(2) if refused.

holdings.text: Termination orders invalid for non-compliance with Clause 10(a) or (b) of Order, even if based on para 4(h) findings of incompetence.

statutes_cited.name: Life Insurance Corporation Act, 1956 (Act 31 of 1956)
statutes_cited.relevance: Transfer of business/employees (s.7,11); power to alter terms (s.11(2)); framing rules/regulations (s.48,49); Order/Regulations derive authority therefrom.

statutes_cited.name: Life Insurance (Emergency Provisions) Ordinance No. 1 of 1956
statutes_cited.relevance: Initial takeover of management pending nationalisation.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Writ jurisdiction; respondents claimed but relief on alternative basis.

statutes_cited.name: Life Insurance Corporation Field Officers (Alteration of Remuneration and other Terms and Conditions of Service) Order, 1957
statutes_cited.relevance: Altered terms for Field/Development Officers; governs termination via Clause 10.

outcome.summary: Appeals dismissed confirming Calcutta High Court orders quashing termination orders and issuing writs; impugned terminations held invalid for non-compliance with Clause 10 of 1957 Order.
outcome.relief_granted: Writs of certiorari and mandamus upheld.

key_quotes.text: "the termination of the services of the said officers must be effected in the manner prescribed by clause 10 of the Order."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding reconciling para 4(h) with Clause 10.

key_quotes.text: "in regard to the Officers to whom the Order applies, if any action is intended to be taken for the termination of their services, it has to be taken under clause 10 a or b."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Establishes mandatory compliance with Order's termination provisions.

key_quotes.text: "the provisions contained in s. 11 (2) of the Act are paramount and would override any contrary provisions contained in the Order or the Regulations."
key_quotes.speaker: court
